Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Fog Networking: Architecture, Algorithms and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The past 15 years have seen the rise of the cloud, along with a rapid increase in Internet backbone traffic and more sophisticated cellular core networks. Some of the responsibilities of these: (1) data centers, (2) backbone IP networks, and (3) cellular core networks, are now descending to be among, or near, the end users, i.e., to the edge of networks. Fog networking is an architecture that uses one or a collaborative multitude of end-user clients or near-user edge devices to carry out a substantial amount of storage, communication and management. Engineering artifacts and applications that reflect such an architecture include 5G, home/personal networking, and the Internet of Things (IoT). It has thus become both feasible and interesting to ask the question: "What can be done on the network edge?" Can it carry out a substantial amount of storage (rather than storing data primarily in large-scale data centers), communication (rather than routing traffic always through the backbone network), and network measurement and control (rather than controlling primarily at gateways like those in the LTE Core)? Potential benefits of fog networking include real-time processing, client-centric objectives, pooling of local resources, rapid innovation with affordable scaling, and feasibility to operate on encrypted and multipath traffic.

There is no shortage of challenges in fog networking, including the following to be tackled in this project: traversing the boundary between centralized and distributed system architectures, steering the global behavior caused by collective client actions, incentivizing client participation, and using redundancy to achieve resilience on the network edge. Among a large and diverse set of topics in fog networking, this project focuses on two themes: (1) Client-driven measurement and inference, including real-time inference of network congestion conditions. Clients can combine local measurements from multiple sources to infer congestion in real time and use these insights to, for instance, optimally preload content at uncongested times. Implementation is achieved by turning client-side SDKs from an app development tool to a network control element. (2) Client-based control and configuration, including control of network connectivity and secure storage. On a fast timescale, client/edge devices can actively optimize their network connectivity by switching between heterogeneous networks, while on a longer timescale, they can relieve network congestion by selectively throttling their data rates. Beyond network connectivity, client-based software can also enhance storage security and reliability by scrambling, shredding and spreading data to different storage spaces.

Broader Impacts: Among this project's industry collaboration, curriculum development, mentoring and outreach are the following highlights. (1) Fog Consortium. Fog networking has the potential to tip the balance of power in the overall IT ecosystem. The PIs help create a Fog Industry-Academia Consortium, which will promote the ideas of fog networking and host outreach events and internship matching open to academia and industry. (2) MOOC. The PIs will offer a new course on "Fog Networking and the Internet of Things," both online and in in-person classes. (3) Community outreach. The PIs will maintain a research website, including a database of papers on fog networking, that is currently hosted at fogresearch.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to investigate the architectural principles and protocol design for fog networking. Fog networking is an architecture that uses one or a collaborative multitude of end-user clients or near-user edge devices to carry out a substantial amount of storage, communication and management. Some of the applications that reflect this architecture include 5G, home/personal networking, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

In achieving our goal of providing architectural and design principals for fog networking to support and enhance these emerging applications, we have derived key results in the following areas:

 

(1) Architectures: we have proposed novel fog computing architectures, and investigated overarching questions on optimal task placement, collaborative learning, and security and privacy, in the fog computing paradigm. In particular, we have developed novel analytical frameworks based on which applications can optimally decompose their components to reside throughout the continuum of things, fog, and the cloud.

(2) Algorithms: we have both analytically and empirically evaluated protocols and algorithms for enabling the operation of fog-based systems, including for scheduling, session management, network selection, and incentive design for managing fog resources. In particular, we proposed edge-based incentive mechanisms to relive network congestion, and evaluated a prototype for commodity wireless routers.

(3) Applications: we have explored fog networking in several application areas including connected drone systems, distributed storage, data offloading in sensor networks, and smart and connected vehicles. In particular, we proposed, implemented, and extensively analyzed a fog-networking based architecture to automatically coordinate drones equipped with camera to broadcast sports games. We also developed a client-centric fog architecture that enables secure distributed storage while maintaining reliability and privacy.

 

Ultimately, this research has provided answers to fundamental questions on ?how to distribute functionalities?, including ?where to compute? and ?where to store?, in the cloud-to-things continuum. We have provided answers to these questions through mathematical modeling and analytical characterizations, numerical simulations based on real-world data, and a number of real-world experiments based on prototypes we have developed.

To promote the ideas of fog networking, the PI co-founded the OpenFog Consortium in 2015, together with cofounders from Cisco, Microsoft, Intel, ARM and Dell. Through several events, whitepapers, industry-academia collaborations, and discussion with IEEE and the NSF, the consortium has worked on an open reference architecture for fog networking. The consortium also organized the first and second World Fog Congress in October 2017 and October 2018, respectively. 

This work has exposed several undergraduate students to advanced interdisciplinary research. Several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers have also participated in these research and teaching efforts, including 6 female graduate students and postdocs.

The first Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) on fog computing and networking was created and launched by the PI in 2016, with tens of thousands of students from around the world enrolled online.

Research conducted during this project has been published in a book co-authored by the PI, and has led to several publications in top-tier conference and journals, poster and conference presentations, and demonstrations. In addition to conference presentations, the work has been widely disseminated through distinguished lectures, keynote lectures, and plenary sessions.
